articles.description:
Posted by Oliver Chang, Google Open Source Security team and Russ Cox, Go team 
In recent months, Google has launched several efforts to strengthen open-source security on multiple fronts. One important focus is improving how we identify and respond to known security vulnerabilities without doing extensive manual work. It is essential to have a precise common data format to triage and remediate security vulnerabilities, particularly when communicating about risks to affected dependencies‚Äîit enables eas‚Ä¶
articles.title: Announcing a unified vulnerability schema for open source

articles.description:
Posted by Kristoffer Janke, Information Security Engineer

Are you ready for no sleep, no chill and a lot of hacking? Our annual Google CTF is back!

The competition kicks off on Saturday July 17 00:00:01 AM UTC  and runs through Sunday July 18 23:59:59 UTC. Teams can register at http://goo.gle/ctf. 

Just like last year, the top 16 teams will qualify for our Hackceler8 speed run and the chance to take home a total of $30,301.70 in prize money.



As we reminisce on last years event, we‚Äôd be remiss if we di‚Ä¶
articles.title: Get ready for the 2021 Google CTF

articles.description:
Posted Kim Lewandowski, Google Open Source Security Team & Mark Lodato, Binary Authorization for Borg Team 

Supply chain integrity attacks‚Äîunauthorized modifications to software packages‚Äîhave been on the rise in the past two years, and are proving to be common and reliable attack vectors that affect all consumers of software. The software development and deployment supply chain is quite complicated, with numerous threats along the source ‚ûû build ‚ûû publish workflow. While point solutions do exist f‚Ä¶
articles.title: Introducing SLSA, an End-to-End Framework for Supply Chain Integrity

articles.description:
Posted by Joel Galenson and Matthew Maurer, Android Team 
One of the main challenges of evaluating Rust for use within the Android platform was ensuring we could provide sufficient interoperability with our existing codebase. If Rust is to meet its goals of improving security, stability, and quality Android-wide, we need to be able to use Rust anywhere in the codebase that native code is required. To accomplish this, we need to provide the majority of functionality platform developers use. As we discussed p‚Ä¶
articles.title: Rust/C++ interop in the Android Platform

articles.description:
Posted by Dan Lorenc, Priya Wadhwa, Open Source Security Team

If you've been paying attention to the news at all lately, you've probably noticed that software supply chain attacks are rapidly becoming a big problem. Whether you're trying to prevent these attacks, responding to an ongoing one or recovering from one, you understand that knowing what is happening in your CI/CD pipeline is critical. 
Fortunately, the Kubernetes-native Tekton project ‚Äì  an open-source framework for creating CI/CD systems ‚Äì was ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Verifiable Supply Chain Metadata for Tekton
Announcing New Abuse Research Grants Program

articles.description:
Posted by Badr Salmi, Google Safe Browsing & Varun Khaneja, Chrome Security 
In 2020 we launched Enhanced Safe Browsing, which you can turn on in your Chrome security settings, with the goal of substantially increasing safety on the web. These improvements are being built on top of existing security mechanisms that already protect billions of devices. Since the initial launch, we have continuously worked behind the scenes to improve our real-time URL checks and apply machine learning models to warn on p‚Ä¶
articles.title: New protections for Enhanced Safe Browsing users in Chrome

articles.description:
By George Pirocanac




A familiar question every software developer and team grapples with is, ‚ÄúHow much testing is enough to qualify a software release?‚Äù A lot depends on the type of software, its purpose, and its target audience. One would expect a far more rigorous approach to testing commercial search engne than a simple smartphone flashlight application. Yet no matter what the application, the question of how much testing is sufficient can be hard to answer in definitive terms. A better approach is to‚Ä¶
articles.title: How Much Testing is Enough?

articles.description:
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer gives us a feel for one of the most exciting new APIs in JavaScript-land.
The Temporal date time API is accessible via the global variable Temporal. It is a pleasure to use:
All objects are immutable. Changing them produces new values, similarly to how strings work in JS.
There is support for time zones and non-Gregorian calendars.
There are several specialized classes for Temporal values (date time values with time zones, date time values without time zones, date values without time zo‚Ä¶
articles.title: Temporal: getting started with JavaScript‚Äôs new date time API

articles.description:
A perspective on incidents that makes a lot of sense actually, and captures the ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù perfectly. My highlights: Incidents involve more people than we think. Tooling just makes it really hard for them to help. We have more incidents than we realise. We just don‚Äôt hear about them. Your whole team, on the same team. Practice makes perfect.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Incidents are for everyone

articles.description:
Brave Search has some similarities to DDG (which has been my default for a couple years now), but it‚Äôs different in that it builds its own index vs relying on Bing and Yandex. Brave‚Äôs principles:
Privacy: no tracking or profiling of users.
User-first: the user comes first, not the advertising and data industries.
Independence: Brave has its own search index for answering common queries privately without reliance on other providers.
Choice: soon, options for ad-free paid search and ad-supported search.
Trans‚Ä¶
articles.title: Brave adds a privacy-focused search engine (beta)

articles.description:
Contributing to open-source projects can be intimidating ‚Äì and PostgreSQL is no exception. As a long-time PostgreSQL contributor, Aleks shares his hard-earned tips to help you make your first contribution, or start contributing more.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: How (and why) to become a PostgreSQL contributor

This week we chat with Angie Jones about all things testing. We‚Äôll cover unit testing, visual testing, end-to-end testing, and more!

articles.description:
Sometimes you start a thing and lose interest. Or maybe it brings in some cash, but not what you‚Äôd hoped. Rather than let it languish and eventually die, sell your thing on Tiny Acquisitions.
Sometimes you want to start a thing, but don‚Äôt have a good idea. Or maybe you‚Äôve tried a few times, but nothing that generated income. Rather than start from scratch with an unproven idea, buy a thing on Tiny Acquisitions.

articles.description:
Andrej Karpathy, Sr. Director of AI at Tesla:
We are going to create, digitally sign, and broadcast a Bitcoin transaction in pure Python, from scratch, and with zero dependencies. In the process we‚Äôre going to learn quite a bit about how Bitcoin represents value. Let‚Äôs get it.
This post is a technical deep-dive. At the end he posted a reader exercise which was to steal some bitcoins his wallet. The challenge, of course, was completed within 45 minutes of publishing. üòÅ
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A from-scratch tour of bitcoin in Python

articles.description:
Kathy Korevec has been putting a lot of thought into documentation as part of her work at GitHub:
Wouldn‚Äôt it be great if the docs knew that you were writing a Python app on a Windows machine and that you preferred watching videos instead of reading through text? I want you to find the answer to your questions in the docs, easily and efficiently. When you‚Äôre stuck on a problem and you turn to the docs, there‚Äôs a moment of magic as you find the solution, try it out and it works. In that moment you become unb‚Ä¶
articles.title: Maybe it‚Äôs time we re-think docs

articles.description:
We discuss how Test Driven Development (TDD) can help you write better code, and build better software. Packed with tips and tricks, gotchas and best practices, the panel explore the subject and share their real-world experiences.

articles.description:
Karsten Silz for InfoQ:
Eight years in the making with 28,000 commits, 7400 pull requests, and 4100 closed issues, Scala 3.0 has been released, delivering a ‚Äúcomplete overhaul of the Scala language‚Äù with new features, updates to the syntax and type systems, and new tools for meta-programming.
Holy wow that must‚Äôve been quite the undertaking. Our Scala coverage is embarrassingly scant. Maybe it‚Äôs time for an episode of The Changelog on the subject? Who would be the ideal guest(s) for such a conversation?
Dis‚Ä¶
articles.title: Scala 3 overhauls language for better developer experience

articles.description:
Chip Huyen has been on both sides of  ML-related interviews and has a lot of expertise on the process:
If you‚Äôve picked up this book because you‚Äôre interested in working with one of the key emerging technologies of the 2020s but not sure where to start, you‚Äôre in the right place. Whether you want to become an ML engineer, a platform engineer, a research scientist, or you want to do ML but don‚Äôt yet know the differences among those titles, I hope that this book will give you some useful pointers.
Discuss on ‚Ä¶
articles.title: A free book on how to survive the machine learning interview process

The New Stack has a solid summary of what‚Äôs new in Grafana 8. Shiny! ‚ú®

articles.title: Grafana 8.0 rethinks alerts and visualizations

articles.description:
This week on Ship It! Gerhard talks with Lars Wikman (independent Elixir/BEAM software consultant) why sometimes a monolith running on a single host with continuous backups and a built-in self-restore capability is everything that a small team of developers needs. That‚Äôs right, no Kubernetes or microservices. After 2 years of running changelog.com, a Phoenix monolith, on Kubernetes, what do I think? Join our discuss and find out!
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 7: Why Kubernetes?

articles.description:
Benny Powers is NOT pleased with what he believes is missing from the latest React release:
For five years now, there‚Äôs been a concerted, multilateral push to bring React into line with every other major framework on custom elements, enshrined in the HTML and DOM specs for years now. Much effort was spent both in public and behind the scenes to encourage the React core team to implement real support for the standards.
But then the PRs were closed, or ignored without public comment. And the issues languished‚Ä¶
articles.title: What's NOT new in React 18

articles.description:
In this article, I‚Äôd like to explore a couple of implementations of sorting algorithms. However, I‚Äôd like to do so driven by unit tests. The examples are written in Go, but don‚Äôt worry if you never worked with Go before. The emphasis here is on the journey and the joy of building solutions guided by tests!
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Let's test-drive some sorting algorithms

articles.description:
A deep-dive on what conditional HTTP requests are, reviewing the main pieces of the RFC, explaining the semantics of validators and preconditions, then showing examples how you can implement conditional HTTP GETs in your web app.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Conditional HTTP GET: The fastest requests need no response body

articles.description:
This talk by Brittany Storoz from JSConf EU 2018 is sooo good! If you‚Äôve ever wondered why we call bugs bugs, why we throw and catch exceptions, or why we use foo and bar as placeholder variables, give it a üëÄ

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The etymology of programming jargon

articles.description:
Pinecone is the first vector database for machine learning.  Edo Liberty explains to Chris how vector similarity search works, and its advantages over traditional database approaches for machine learning.  It enables one to search through billions of vector embeddings for similar matches, in milliseconds, and Pinecone is a managed service that puts this capability at the fingertips of machine learning practitioners.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and‚Ä¶
articles.title: Practical AI 139: Vector databases for machine learning

articles.description:
This project is no longer actively developed, but it looks like an excellent resource for anyone who is interested in compilers. Ruby is an easy language to grok, so it should make for (relatively) easy reading!
Rhizome is a paedagogical just-in-time compiler (JIT) for Ruby, implemented in pure Ruby. It‚Äôs not really designed to be used. It‚Äôs designed to show you how JITs work and why perhaps a JIT for Ruby should be written in Ruby. It‚Äôs also designed to try to go beyond the trivial aspects of a simple temp‚Ä¶
articles.title: A pure-Ruby JIT compiler for Ruby (read it, don't use it!)

articles.description:
The general idea is to leverage cache-friendly ways of organizing data in structures of arrays (SoA) otherwise known ‚Äúcolumnar‚Äù storage in database design. This, in turn allows us to iterate and filter over columns very efficiently. On top of that, this package also adds bitmap indexing to the columnar storage, allowing to build filter queries using binary and, and not, or and xor (see kelindar/bitmap with SIMD support).
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A high-performance, columnar, in-memory storage engine for Go

articles.description: AugLy is a great library to utilize for augmenting your data in model training, or to evaluate the robustness gaps of your model! We designed AugLy to include many specific data augmentations that users perform in real life on internet platforms like Facebook‚Äôs ‚Äì for example making an image into a meme, overlaying text/emojis on images/videos, reposting a screenshot from social media. While AugLy contains more generic data augmentations as well, it will be particularly useful to you if you‚Äôre working on a p‚Ä¶
articles.title: A data augmentations library for audio, image, text, and video

articles.description:
On this episode we‚Äôre talking with our good friend Mat Ryer whom you may know from the Go Time podcast. Mat created an awesome open source tool for putting just about anything in your Mac‚Äôs toolbar. It was originally written in Objective-C, but it just got a big rewrite in Go and abig  rename from BitBar to xbar.
If you don‚Äôt use a Mac don‚Äôt hit skip on this episode quite yet! There are lessons to be learned for anyone interested in hacking on tools to make your life better. Plus, with this rewrite Mat has ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 446: xbar puts anything in your macOS menu bar

articles.description:
You sigh. Maybe the compilation didn‚Äôt work? You recompile and run it again. Nope. Still the same problem. You stare out the window.
This post is about ways of getting unstuck on a problem when you do not (yet) have all the relevant knowledge. It focuses on the problem with the ego when being a more seasoned programmer and the difficulty on admitting that you don‚Äôt know (yet).
From there we go through the steps on being unstuck and making that ego more inflated and annoying.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Getting unstuck

articles.description:
Super Mario World Widescreen is your beloved Mario World SNES game but in the 16:9 resolution. This is possible by expanding the horizontal resolution by 96 pixels, increasing resolution from 256x224 to 352x224. Since the original SNES does not have this resolution, the emulator focused into high definition mods bsnes-hd must be used.
I love how open source hackers give classic games like this new life by applying their skill and ingenuity to a property they love. I wonder if having it in widescreen changes‚Ä¶
articles.title: Super Mario World modded to be 16:9

articles.description: This week we‚Äôre talking with Pia Mancini about the latest updates to the mission of Open Collective. Earlier this year Open Collective announced ‚ÄúFunds for Open Source.‚Äù The idea is simple, make it easy for companies to invest in open source, and they will. Also, since recording this episode, Pia and the team at Open Collective along with Gitcoin announced fundoss.org as part of Maintainer Week announcements. And right now, they have a matching fund of $75,000 dollars funding open source that you can suppor‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 445: Funds for open source

Yulia Startsev from Mozilla‚Äôs SpiderMonkey team joins Jerod & Feross to talk compilers, going back to get your Master‚Äôs, making decisions as a group, process of shepherding a feature through TC39, how Firefox actually works, and LavaMoats. Yes, LavaMoats.

This animated ‚Äúchildren‚Äôs‚Äù book is spectacularly good. It centers around a growing community of otters, their struggles to communicate efficiently, and one little otter named Nixie‚Äôs great idea that changed the forest forever.
Put, put, put your events

articles.description:
DenoDB has a fully-typed API (which is great for editor integration) and supports a whole host of backends: MySQL/Maria, SQLite, Postgres, and MongoDB.
Broad database support is great for library adoption, but as a user I‚Äôd prefer something that leans in to a specific ecosystem, which usually lets you squeeze more out of it.
Regardless of that, it‚Äôs great to see the Deno community building foundational tools like this.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Deno gets an ORM

articles.description:
What you will see next is a highly subjective, non-exhaustive unordered list of principles that, if you follow, I can guarantee will lead you to become a bad developer‚Ä¶
If your goal, fellow reader, is to become a good developer instead, don‚Äôt worry. Remember that via negativa is way more powerful than via positiva. That means that knowing what not to do is safer and easier to figure out than exactly what to do. So pay attention to the following topics and decide which type of developer you want to be.
I (di‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to become a bad developer

articles.description:
A bad CLI can easily discourage users from interacting with it. Building successful CLIs requires attention to detail and empathy for the user in order to create a good user experience. It is very easy to get wrong.
In this guide I have compiled a list of best practices across areas of focus which aim to optimize for an ideal user experience when interacting with a CLI application.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: The largest Node.js CLI Apps best practices list ‚ú®

articles.description:
Porter lets you package your application artifacts, client tools, configuration and deployment logic together as a versioned bundle that you can distribute, and then install with a single command. Written entirely in Go, we speak to one of the creators about running an open source project, the importance of documentation, and more.
Discuss on Changelog News

Sponsors
Teleport ‚Äì¬†Teleport Access Plane lets you access any‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Yejun Su is using Numerical Elixir‚Äôs new Livebook project for more than just Numerical Things.
Before Livebook, I write code in IEx, which is a REPL. It has some helpers to ease the way to explore code, but in my opinion, Livebook exceeds in two factors:
Code history
export ERL_AFLAGS="-kernel shell_history enabled" in the shell profile file. You can also search the IEx code history with Ctrl-r and apply it. But as Livebook is essentially a notebook, you can see all texts and evaluation results wi‚Ä¶
articles.title: Livebook-driven development

articles.description:
Utopia is an integrated design and development environment for React. It uses React code as the source of truth, and lets you make real time changes to components by editing it and using a suite of design tools. It‚Äôs early software, but you can try it today, look at an example project, or read about it on our blog!

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: An integrated design and development environment for React

articles.description:
This week on Ship It! Gerhard talks with Ian Miell, author of Docker in Practice as well as Learn Git, Bash, and Terraform the Hard Way. They talk about being comfortable with the uncomfortable, focusing on the tech while keeping a holistic view of the business. Following the money is key. Ian explains this concept really well, and Gerhard feels fairly confident you will be better off if you pay attention. Let us know in the comments!
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get close‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Matthew Gerstman:
I‚Äôve been tasked with leading frontend. As a result, I‚Äôve been teaching a whole lot of people about the web.
Knowing where we came from can help us figure out where we should go. It‚Äôs also a mountain of technical debt, and we‚Äôre collectively building on top of it.
Forgive me if I skip the wonderful stories of Macromedia Flash, Java in the browser, or whatever other detour you can think of. While those were important to development of the web, most of us will never run into them again.
The ‚Ä¶
articles.title: History of the web: part 1

articles.description:
You‚Äôve probably seen many of these commands hit Changelog News over the years, but now you can see them all again in one hand-curated place. Who knows, maybe one or two will be new to you. I hadn‚Äôt heard of curlie previously, which looks like a nice merging of cur and httpie.
Discuss on Changelog News

articles.description:
Prestige rivals rich HTTP clients such as Postman and Insomnia by being‚Ä¶ less rich. BUT. All you have to do is fire it up in your browser and type out some plain text. So straight forward!

articles.description:
A quick list of 23 skills for varying levels of seniority, from senior, to staff, and beyond. My favorites from the list are How to listen to other engineers‚Äô ideas without feeling threatened (#10) and How to pick your battles (#18) .
Everyone else‚Äôs favorite, according to the top highlight,  is How to get someone promoted (#19).
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: An incomplete list of skills senior engineers need, beyond coding

articles.description: William Falcon wants AI practitioners to spend more time on model development, and less time on engineering. PyTorch Lightning is a lightweight PyTorch wrapper for high-performance AI research that lets you train on multiple-GPUs, TPUs, CPUs and even in 16-bit precision without changing your code! In this episode, we dig deep into Lightning, how it works, and what it is enabling. William also discusses the Grid AI platform (built on top of PyTorch Lightning). This platform lets you seamlessly train 100s of ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Practical AI 138: Multi-GPU training is hard (without PyTorch Lightning)

articles.description:
When it comes to scaling, we might need to think about:
data storage, if we store more and more data and it becomes expensive or slow working with them
fast INSERTs and UPDATES for write-heavy workloads
making SELECT queries faster because of their complexity or because they need to query huge amounts of data
concurrency if we have many clients interacting with the database
In this article, I will present some basic ideas and starting points on scaling traditional SQL databases.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Scaling relational SQL databases

articles.description:
WWDC21 wasn‚Äôt the most exciting Apple keynote ever (especially for those of us hoping for some new hardware), but there were a lot of software things announced. Apple continues to iterate on Swift, and the new 5.5 beta has some really cool stuff in it. InfoQ has the rundown on its two flagship improvements.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Swift 5.5 brings async/await and actor support

articles.description:
Don Watkins:
Mark Van Doren said, ‚Äúthe art of teaching is the art of assisting discovery.‚Äù I saw that play out in this classroom using open source tools. More students need opportunities like this to help them gain a quality education. The Raspberry Pi 400 is a great form factor for teaching and learning.
Such a cool program that‚Äôd be easy to reproduce in your local library.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: How I teach Python on the Raspberry Pi 400 at the public library

Tanner joins Nick to talk about his projects, react-query and react table, and discuss scratching your own itch in a maintainable way with open source.

Retool ‚Äì¬†Retool is a low-code platform built specifically for developers that makes it fast and easy to build internal tools. Instead of building internal tools from scratch, the world‚Äôs best teams, from startups to Fortune 500s, are ‚Ä¶
articles.title: JS Party 179: Building on the TanStack

articles.description: OldOS is a testament to the days of yesteryear, showcasing what iOS once was ten years ago. The ethos of the app is to merge the technologies of today with a pixel-perfect recreation of the user experience of the past. The vast majority of apps in OldOS are fully functional ‚Äî meaning they seamlessly integrate with the data on your phone to deliver a live, emulator-esque experience. What does this mean? Well, you can play your music in iPod, get directions in Maps, surf the web in Safari, view the current we‚Ä¶
articles.title: Recreating a fully functional version of iOS 4 in SwiftUI

articles.description:
This bold statement starts a long Twitter thread by Brantly Millegan:
‚ÄúSign-In w/ Ethereum‚Äù is the future of login for every app on the Internet, crypto-related or not. Not just an idea, it‚Äôs already the norm for web3 & will spread.
This idea was the most interesting/exciting thing for me that came out of our NFT talk with Mikeal Rogers. Could cryptocurrency be the carrot that attracts the masses to obtain a public/private key pair and be financially incentivized to secure it? If so, this makes for a fa‚Ä¶
articles.title: "The Ethereum community has accidentally solved a major problem of the Internet: Single Sign-On"

articles.description:
This episode was recorded live from GopherCon Europe 2021!
Natalie & Mat host three amazing devs who gave talks that showcase using Go in unusual ways: Dr. Joakim Kennedy is tracking Go in malware, Mathilde Raynal is building quantum-resistant cryptography algorithms, and Preslav Rachev is creating digital art.
We hear from our speakers how they got into Go, how they made the choice to use Go for their unusual use case, and how it compares to other languages for their specific needs.
We also chat about ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Go Time 183: Using Go in unusual ways

articles.description:
When it comes to open source, we came for the code, but we stayed for the people. Some of the best, brightest, & kindest people we‚Äôve met over our years doing The Changelog are maintainers of open source software.
We‚Äôve been working (alongside others) to support, encourage, and shine our spotlight on these amazing people for awhile now, so it was exciting to hear that our friends at GitHub and Tidelift were organizing Maintainer Week.
If you listened to our Maintainer Week episode, then you already know‚Ä¶
articles.title: Thank a maintainer on us!

articles.description:
Maintainer Week is finally here and we‚Äôre excited to make this an annual thing! If Maintainer Week is new to you, check out episode #442 with Josh Simmons and Kara Sowles.
Today we‚Äôre talking Brett Cannon. Brett is Dev Manager of the Python Extension for VS Code, Python Steering Council Member, and core team member for Python. He recently shared a blog post The social contract of open source, so we invited Brett to join us for Maintainer Week to discuss this topic in detail.
Thank a maintainer on us! We‚Äôre ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 444: Every commit is a gift

articles.description: This week on Ship It! Gerhard talks with Dave Farley, co-author of Continuous Delivery and the inventor of the Deployment Pipeline. Today, most of us ship code the way we do because 25 years ago, Dave cared enough to drive the change that we now call CI/CD. He is one of the great software engineers: opinionated, perseverant & focused since the heydays of the internet. Dave continues inspiring and teaching us all via his newly launched YouTube channel, courses and recent books. The apprentice finally mee‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 5: The foundations of Continuous Delivery

articles.description:
Miroslav Nikolov:
You may not be a project manager. Perhaps you are a developer who likes to code and solve technical challenges. The organizational matter is something you care less about. After all, your company is likely relying on some agile methods and there are product owners and/or SCRUM masters to handle the process. You just need to build new features.
While that‚Äôs true you have to sometimes get out of your comfort zone.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Arguments for a project kickoff strategy

articles.description:
When we had Adam Wathan on JS Party, I asked him if anybody besides the Tailwind team were working on component libraries. He said yes, but didn‚Äôt name any off the top of his head. Well, add DaisyUI to the list.
Your HTML doesn‚Äôt need to be messy. DaisyUI adds component classes to Tailwind CSS. Classes like btn, card, etc‚Ä¶ No need to deal with hundreds of utility classes.
No script dependencies. 2KB gzipped. Worth a look.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: DaisyUI ‚Äì component classes for Tailwind

articles.description:
Adam and Jerod sit down to answer a listener question (Hi, Alex! üëã) about how we podcast. Not how we create podcasts, but how we consume podcasts. Along the way we share an update on our comments feature, discuss the Apple Podcasts rollout debacle (and how it affected us launching Ship It!), and give a few personal recommendations of podcasts we‚Äôre listening to.

articles.description:
LJ Miranda:
When I first saw ‚ÄúAvengers: Endgame‚Äù in theaters, I noticed that their time travel rule is quite similar to the Git branching model. Referred to as the time heist, our heroes travelled through time to recover the stones‚Ä¶
I had to truncate that pull quote to avoid Avengers spoilers. If you‚Äôve seen the movie (or don‚Äôt care about getting spoiled) there‚Äôs some good Git knowledge to be gained from this analogy.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: What can "Avengers: Endgame" teach us about Git?

articles.description:
Chris and Daniel sit down to chat about some exciting new AI developments including wav2vec-u (an unsupervised speech recognition model) and meta-learning (a new book about ‚ÄúHow To Learn Deep Learning And Thrive In The Digital World‚Äù). Along the way they discuss engineering skills for AI developers and strategies for launching AI initiatives in established companies.

articles.description:
Althttpd is a simple webserver that has run the sqlite.org website since 2004. Althttpd strives for simplicity, security, and low resource usage.
As of 2018, the althttpd instance for sqlite.org answers about 500,000 HTTP requests per day (about 5 or 6 per second) delivering about 50GB of content per day (about 4.6 megabits/second) on a $40/month Linode. The load average on this machine normally stays around 0.1 or 0.2. About 19% of the HTTP requests are CGI to various Fossil source-code repositories.
Richa‚Ä¶
articles.title: Richard Hipp's single file webserver written in C

articles.description:
Brendan Gregg tells a tale from 2005:
This is the story of the most unbelievable demo I‚Äôve been given in world of open source. You can‚Äôt make this stuff up.
I don‚Äôt want to ruin it, so I‚Äôll just say that it‚Äôs not unbelievable in the way you might think it‚Äôs unbelievable.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: An unbelievable demo

articles.description:
This week we‚Äôre joined by Ryan Dahl, Node.js creator, and now the creator of Deno - a simple, modern and secure runtime for JavaScript and TypeScript that uses V8 and is built in Rust.
We talk with Ryan about the massive success of Node and how it impacted his life, how he eventually created Deno and what he‚Äôs doing differently this time around. We also talk about The Deno Company, and what‚Äôs in store for Deno Delpoy.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, a‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Changelog 443: Exploring Deno Land ü¶ï

Powered by Mediapipe, TensorFlow, and Jeeliz.

articles.description:
I was clueless how big and competitive a marketplace Chrome extensions are until Oleg Anashkin decided to document all of the proposals he‚Äôs received over the years to monetize Hover Zoom+. His reasoning:
The main reason I continue to maintain this extension is because I can hardly trust others to not fall for one of these offers. I‚Äôm fortunate to have a job that pays well enough to allow me to keep my moral compass and ignore all of these propositions. I realize that not everyone has the same financial sec‚Ä¶
articles.title: Chrome extension devs get hit up incessantly with monetization proposals

articles.description:
We first talked fuzzing with Katie Hockman back in August of 2020. Fast-forward 10 months and native fuzzing in Go is ready for beta testing! Here‚Äôs Katie explaining fuzzing, for the uninitiated:
Fuzzing is a type of automated testing which continuously manipulates inputs to a program to find issues such as panics or bugs. These semi-random data mutations can discover new code coverage that existing unit tests may miss, and uncover edge case bugs which would otherwise go unnoticed. Since fuzzing can reach t‚Ä¶
articles.title: Go's fuzzing effort now in beta

articles.description:
Eric Simons and the StackBlitz team recently announced WebContainers which let you run Node.js natively in your browser! This has BIG implications and leaves us with many BIG questions like: how did they do it, why did they do it, and where does it go from here? Tune in! Keyword: BIG
Discuss on Changelog News

Nick Janetakis shares a few patterns he‚Äôs picked up based on using Docker since 2014 for many freelance projects. He also posted a timestamped video version on YouTube if you‚Äôd prefer to watch over reading.

articles.title: Best practices around production ready web apps with Docker Compose

articles.description:
Most people who use GraphQL haven‚Äôt read the spec, often because it sounds or looks intimidating. This post simply and cogently shares the essentials of the query language section of the spec.

articles.title: The GraphQL spec, simplified

articles.description:
If you updated your Firefox to version 89 and were not-so-pleasantly surprised by the brand new Proton interface, this Lepton project may be of interest to you. Lepton doesn‚Äôt throw Proton out with the bath water, but aims to improve some key aspects the author didn‚Äôt appreciate.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: An attempt to improve Firefox's new Proton UI

articles.description: Open Source Insights is an experimental service developed and hosted by Google to help developers better understand the structure, construction, and security of open source software packages. The service examines each package, constructs a full, detailed graph of its dependencies and their properties, and makes the results available to anyone who could benefit from them. The goal is to provide developers with a picture of how their software is put together, how that changes as dependencies change, and what ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Google's experimental Open Source Insights project

articles.description:
In the past decade a variety of games have emerged where players need to create an AI to play the game rather than play the game directly. In this episode we speak with the creator of one of those games - Battlesnake. Brad Van Vugt joins us to talk about building a game engine using Go, making programming games easier for beginners to get started with, the long term vision for games like Battlesnake, and more.
Discuss on Changelog News
Join Changelog++ to support our work, get closer to the metal, and make ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Go Time 182: Go Battlesnake Go!

articles.description:
I hadn‚Äôt heard of Prosus prior to this announcement, so if you‚Äôre at all like me, this is for you:
Prosus invests globally across a range of online platforms focused on areas such as food delivery, classifieds and fintech. It also maintains a more than $200 billion holding in Tencent. Prosus‚Äô parent company, Naspers Ltd., acquired the Tencent stake in 2001 for $34 million.
Turning $34 million into $200 billion is quite the feat. They‚Äôre a savvy bunch, if nothing else. Joel Spolsky also wrote about the acqui‚Ä¶
articles.title: Stack Overflow sold to tech giant Prosus for $1.8 billion

articles.description:
Due to concerns over control of user information, multiple volunteers have resigned from Freenode to found Libera Chat. This FAQ notes:
What it appears to come down to, is that Andrew Lee is attempting to essentially take over the network by drowning staff in lawyers.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: Libera Chat ‚Äì  a next-gen IRC network for FOSS projects

articles.description:
Craig Kerstiens:
Postgres has had ‚ÄúJSON‚Äù support for nearly 10 years now. I put JSON in quotes because well, 10 years ago when we announced JSON support we kinda cheated. We validated JSON was valid and then put it into a standard text field. Two years later in 2014 with Postgres 9.4 we got more proper JSON support with the JSONB datatype. My colleague @will likes to state that the B stands for better. In Postgres 14, the JSONB support is indeed getting way better.
A small but solid improvement to how you q‚Ä¶
articles.title: Better JSON in Postgres with PostgreSQL 14

articles.description:
This is the resource that Una Kravets said we‚Äôd put in the show notes on JS Party #176. I thought it was worth a direct linking in News as well, since it‚Äôs so freakin‚Äô well-done and useful:
You‚Äôll learn CSS fundamentals like the box model, cascade and specificity, flexbox, grid and z-index. And, along with these fundamentals, you‚Äôll learn about functions, color types, gradients, logical properties and inheritance to make you a well-rounded front-end developer, ready to take on any user interface.
Discuss on‚Ä¶
articles.title: An evergreen CSS course and reference to level up your web styling expertise
Command-line tools for speech and intent recognition on Linux

articles.description: This week on Ship It! Gerhard talks with Ben Ford, former Royal Marine and founder of Commando Development, about the OODA loop (observe, orient, decide, act). Shipping is just a small part of it. The OODA loop that you know is probably the wrong one. We explore Mission & Command, Situational Awareness and a few other practices that will help you deal with complexity as you code and ship. As a former Royal Marine Commando, Ben learned these skills the hard way, and then refined them over many years as a‚Ä¶
articles.title: Ship It! 4: OODA for operational excellence

articles.description:
Tuhin Srivastava tells Daniel and Chris why BaseTen is the application development toolkit for data scientists.  BaseTen‚Äôs goal is to make it simple to serve machine learning models, write custom business logic around them, and expose those through API endpoints without configuring any infrastructure.

Try it now with JupyterLab and/or RetroLab.

articles.description:
Boring avatars is a tiny JavaScript React library that generates custom, SVG-based, round avatars from any username and color palette.
Cool, but it‚Äôd be even cooler if it detached from React so we could all use it. It‚Äôd also be nice if you could opt to having the initials overlay the gradient.

Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A little React library to replace your boring fallback avatars

articles.description:
Sometimes to solve a problem we tend to choose a set of tools we got used to. How often we pick a tool just because we know it, and not necessarily because it‚Äôs the right one for a task at hand? These are my rules to overcome that.
Discuss on Changelog News
articles.title: A hacker mindset

articles.description: Have you ever noticed that the word art is embedded in the phrase artificial intelligence? Neither did we, but when the opportunity presented itself to explore how artificial intelligence (AI) inspires artistic expression ‚Äî with the help of internationally renowned Canadian artist Douglas Coupland ‚Äî the Google Research team jumped on it. This collaboration, with the support of Google Arts & Culture, culminated in a project called Slogans for the Class of 2030, which spotlights the experiences of the fir‚Ä¶
articles.title: Douglas Coupland fuses AI and art to inspire students

articles.description:
Over recent years, we have seen remarkable progress in AI‚Äôs ability to confront new problems and help solve old ones. Advancing these efforts was one reason we set up the Google Research India lab in 2019, with a particular emphasis on AI research that could make a positive social impact. It‚Äôs also why we've supported nonprofit organizations through the Google AI Impact Challenge.

Working in partnership with Google.org and Google‚Äôs University Relations program, our goal is to help academics and nonprofits ‚Ä¶
articles.title: How we‚Äôre supporting 30 new AI for Social Good projects

articles.description: This part 2. See Giving a away an insane amount of curl stickers for part 1. As suspected already from the start, I ran out of stickers really fast. I ordered more from my trusted sticker guy on the corner, and he could even deliver stickers put into pre-printed envelopes. Envelopes that even got a … Continue reading Sending those stickers →
articles.title: Sending those stickers

articles.description: On May 17, I joined the Kathy and Brian, the hosts of the GitHub ReadMe podcast on a video meeting from my home and we had a chat. Mostly about my work on curl. Today the episode “aired”. “curl: 25 years and 200 releases later” You find it here. Also: Spotify. Apple podcasts. RSS feed. … Continue reading On the GitHub ReadMe podcast →
articles.title: On the GitHub ReadMe podcast

articles.description: curl is a command line tool and library for doing Internet data transfers. It has been around for a loooong time (over 23 years) but there is still a flood of new things being added to it and development being made, to take it further and to keep it relevant today and in the future. … Continue reading What goes into curl? →
articles.title: What goes into curl?

articles.description: In the afternoon of October 17, 2013 we merged the first config file ever that would use Travis CI for the curl project using the nifty integration at GitHub. This was the actual introduction of the entire concept of building and testing the project on every commit and pull request for the curl project. Before … Continue reading Bye bye Travis CI →
articles.title: Bye bye Travis CI

articles.description: In 2012 I wrote a blog post titled curling the metalink, describing how we added support for metalink to curl. Today, we remove that support again. This is a very drastic move, and I feel obliged to explain it so here it goes! curl 7.78.0 will ship without metalink support. Metalink problems There were several … Continue reading Bye bye metalink in curl →
articles.title: Bye bye metalink in curl

articles.description: When you use the name localhost in a URL, what does it mean? Where does the network traffic go when you ask curl to download http://localhost ? Is “localhost” just a name like any other or do you think it infers speaking to your local host on a loopback address? Previously curl http://localhost The name … Continue reading curl localhost as a local host →
articles.title: curl localhost as a local host

articles.description: Companies offer ongoing bug bounties to freelance ethical hackers to discover security vulnerabilities. Alternatively, penetration testing is a scheduled test of a system‚Äôs security to identify weaknesses and vulnerabilities.
articles.title: Bug Bounty vs. Penetration Testing: 	Differences Explained

articles.description: Hundreds of HackerOne customers use our platform in their application security processes. For the most part, these are organizations using bug bounty to find vulnerabilities in their deployed applications. But there is so much more that we can do for development teams
articles.title: HackerOne in DevSecOps

articles.description: Vulnerability scanning helps companies identify possible ways an attacker could exploit vulnerabilities that might cause outages, allow unauthorized network access, or acquisition of privileged information. Outdated software products, unpatched operating systems, and misconfigured hardware often lead to vulnerabilities.
articles.title: What is Vulnerability Scanning? [And How to Do It Right]

articles.description: Developers need to bring security into their workflows without pivoting to separate security tools to get vulnerability information. HackerOne has created an integration with GitHub to streamline the process of including more security in the Software Development Life Cycle.
articles.title: How HackerOne and GitHub Now Work Better Together

articles.description: We recently sat down with Abhijith Chandrashekar, PSIRT Manager at Citrix, to discuss why Citrix continues to expand their bug bounty program and learn about their cloud security and scope expansion plans. Read on to see what he had to say.
articles.title: Citrix‚Äôs Hacker-Powered Security Growth Plan: Q&A with Abhijith Chandrashekar

articles.description: HackerOne recently hosted AWS and a panel of expert ethical hackers to discuss how Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerabilities and cloud misconfiguration are ripe environments for hackers to discover vulnerabilities and improve their skills. In addition, they both represent significant and multi-layered security risks for many organizations.
articles.title: How Hackers Can Help Reduce Your Organization's Application Risk on AWS

articles.description: Penetration testing, aka pen testing or ethical hacking, attempts to attempt to breach a system's security for the purpose of vulnerability identification. Testing is done in an authorized and structured manner to report and rectify so that weaknesses can be reported and rectified.
articles.title: What is Penetration Testing? How Does It Work Step-by-Step?

articles.description: It's been 60 days since the DoD's Defense Industrial Base Vulnerability Disclosure Program (DIB-VDP) pilot launched. In this blog, DC3 and HackerOne sit down to talk about the pilot‚Äôs early successes, learnings to date, and their goals for the future.
articles.title: 60 days of insights from the DoD‚Äôs Defense Industrial Base Vulnerability Disclosure Program Pilot

articles.description: HackerOne sat down with DDS and Army program leaders and one of the security researchers who hacked the Army. We discussed why Hack the matters, the results that were uncovered in Hack the Army 3.0, and their plans for the future of cybersecurity within the DoD and the U.S. Military. Read on to see what they had to say.
articles.title: Announcing Hack the Army 3.0 Results: A Conversation with Defense Digital Service, U.S. Army, and Hack the Army 3.0‚Äôs Top Hacker

articles.description: Reducing risk is the fundamental reason organizations invest in cybersecurity. As the threat landscape grows and evolves, organizations need a proactive approach to building and protecting their security posture.
articles.title: Build a Resilient Security Posture with Vulnerability Intelligence and Cybersecurity Ratings

articles.description: In March, Amazon sponsored HackerOne‚Äôs 10-day, virtual hacking event, which attracted more than 50 security researchers to identify potential vulnerabilities across Amazon‚Äôs core assets. Read on for highlights from the event.
articles.title: Hack Hard. Have Fun. Increase Security

articles.description: Last week, HackerOne joined WhiteSource, AWS, and IGT for a roundtable discussion about the new security challenges of digital transformation. The panel discussed cloud security, software supply chain security, and vulnerability disclosure programs as examples of proactive approaches organizations can take to mitigate their risk.
articles.title: How Digital Transformation Changes An Organization's Security Challenges

articles.description: Microsoft says the state-backed Russian hacker group Nobelium‚Äîthe same actor behind the 2020 SolarWinds attacks‚Äîtook control of the State Department‚Äôs United States Agency for International Development email system. This bold attack, expected to be ongoing, breached federal government supplier systems sending out official-looking emails to over 3,000 accounts across more than 150 organizations.
articles.title: Microsoft Says: Russian SolarWinds Hackers Hit U.S. Government Agencies Again

articles.description:
When implementing a language feature for JavaScript, an implementer must make decisions about how the language in the specification maps to the implementation. Private fields is an example of where the specification language and implementation reality diverge, at least in SpiderMonkey‚Äì the JavaScript engine which powers Firefox. To understand more, I‚Äôll explain what private fields are, a couple of models for thinking about them, and explain why our implementation diverges from the specification language.
Th‚Ä¶
articles.sourceTitle: Mozilla Hacks ‚Äì the Web developer blog
articles.title: Implementing Private Fields for JavaScript

articles.description:
Firefox 89 has smartened up and brings with it a slimmed-down, slightly more minimalist interface.
Along with this new look, we get some great styling features including a force-colours feature for media queries and better control over how fonts are displayed. The long-awaited top-level await keyword for JavaScript modules is now enabled, as well as the PerformanceEventTiming interface, which is another addition to the performance suite of APIs: 89 really has been working out!
The post Looking fine with Fir‚Ä¶
articles.sourceTitle: Mozilla Hacks ‚Äì the Web developer blog
articles.title: Looking fine with Firefox 89

articles.description: GitHub‚Äôs bug bounty program is now a mature component of how we improve product security. We're excited to highlight some achievements (and interesting vulnerabilities)!
articles.title: Seven years of the GitHub Security Bug Bounty program

articles.description: We're excited to announce the newest addition to the Student Developer Pack, the GitHub Virtual Event Kit! Access the best virtual event tools in one place at no cost.
articles.title: Run online campus events with your favorite tools at no cost with the new GitHub Virtual Event Kit

articles.description: Announcing new beta features for GitHub Issues for better planning and tracking of your projects in GitHub, including project tables, task lists, and issue forms.
articles.title: Introducing the new GitHub Issues

articles.description: We recently set about creating a framework and service for automatically generating social sharing images for repositories and other resources on GitHub.
articles.title: A framework for building Open Graph images

articles.description: Throughout the beta, we added features to improve the experience of using the Container registry. Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce that the Container registry is generally available as part of GitHub Packages!

articles.title: GitHub Desktop 2.9 includes squashing, reordering, amending, and more!

articles.description: What began as a small group effort in 2015 has now turned into a global initiative here at GitHub to amplify Black voices and talent in the tech community.
articles.title: Blacktocats turn five

articles.description: In May, GitHub shipped a total of 20 new features. We love what we do, but we know it‚Äôs a lot to keep up with. So we‚Äôre trying something new on the GitHub Blog‚Äîa monthly recap of everything that shipped to Changelog in the past month. Check out some of the updates you might have missed.
articles.title: What‚Äôs new from GitHub Changelog? May 2021 Recap

articles.description: polkit is a system service installed by default on many Linux distributions. It‚Äôs used by systemd, so any Linux distribution that uses systemd also uses polkit. As a member of GitHub Security Lab, my job is to help improve the security of open source software by finding and reporting vulnerabilities. A few weeks ago, I found a privilege escalation vulnerability in polkit.
articles.title: Privilege escalation with polkit: How to get root on Linux with a seven-year-old bug

articles.description: GitHub secret scanning has been securing our users‚Äô code by scanning for and revoking secrets since 2015. Recently, we‚Äôve focused on scanning for package registry credentials as well—a significant and important expansion on our original
articles.title: Securing the open source supply chain by scanning for package registry credentials

articles.description: One month ago, we started a discussion with the community about proposed revisions to clarify GitHub‚Äôs policies on security research, malware, and exploits with the goal to enable, welcome, and encourage dual-use security research and
articles.title: Updates to our policies regarding exploits, malware, and vulnerability research

articles.description: We’ve seen some amazing community projects this last month. This was a huge month for your community with hundreds of new releases. There‚Äôs everything from world-changing tech to weekend hobbies. It was almost too hard
articles.title: Release Radar ¬∑ May 2021 Edition

articles.description: GitHub Enterprise Server 3.1 is now generally available for all customers. It helps customers work with large, busy repositories, while enabling developers to develop and deploy with less effort than ever. This release includes: GitHub
articles.title: GitHub Enterprise Server 3.1 is now generally available

articles.description: In May, we experienced two incidents resulting in significant impact to multiple GitHub services.
articles.title: GitHub Availability Report: May 2021

articles.description: We‚Äôre proud to share the new and improved Social Impact at GitHub website, and we‚Äôre really excited to share what our team has been working on! GitHub‚Äôs mission is to advance human progress. Our part
articles.title: Github Social Impact: How we‚Äôre driving change with social sector organizations

articles.description:
A huge part of Nubank‚Äôs Data Science team has been recently focusing on leveraging causal inference along with traditional machine learning to solve some of our toughest problems. This post aims at explaining why causal inference is such a powerful tool to solve business problems with data.
The post Beyond prediction machines appeared first on Building Nubank.
articles.title: Beyond prediction machines

Series G becomes the largest private capital raise by a technology company in Latin America ever.

articles.title: Nubank closes a second extension to its Series G round raising it to US$1.15B
